video.title: Algorithmic Trading Using Python - Full Course
video.description:
Learn how to perform algorithmic trading using Python in this complete course. Algorithmic trading means using computers to make investment decisions. Computer algorithms can make trades at a speed and frequency that is not possible by a human.

After learning the basics of algorithmic trading, you will learn how to build three algorithmic trading projects.

💻 Code: https://github.com/nickmccullum/algorithmic-trading-python

✏️ Course developed by Nick McCullum. Learn more about Nick here: https://nickmccullum.com/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Algorithmic Trading Fundamentals & API Basics
⌨️ (0:17:20) Building An Equal-Weight S&P 500 Index Fund
⌨️ (1:38:44) Building A Quantitative Momentum Investing Strategy
⌨️ (2:54:02) Building A Quantitative Value Investing Strategy

Note that this course is meant for educational purposes only. The data and information presented in this video is not investment advice. One benefit of this course is that you get access to unlimited scrambled test data (rather than live production data), so that you can experiment as much as you want without risking any money or paying any fees.

This course is original content created by freeCodeCamp. This content was created using data and a grant provided by IEX Cloud. You can learn more about IEX Cloud here: https://iexcloud.io/

Any opinions or assertions contained herein do not represent the opinions or beliefs of IEX Cloud, its third-party data providers, or any of its affiliates or employees.

topLevelComment.author: Alex Suero
topLevelComment.text:
Amazing video! Thank you so much for sharing this! Still going through it, but there's an observation I need to make for any beginners that might stumble upon this video:

To create a new column with values based on another column(s), using a for loop to iterate through rows  and make calculations (as shown in 2:31:11) will be EXTREMELY inefficient on larger datasets. It is better to use Pandas' `apply()` method paired with a `lambda` function, as follows:
```
# create list with time periods
time_period = ['One-Year', 'Six-Month', 'Three-Month', 'One-Month']

# create new fields (or update existing ones) based on previous list 
# and calculate percentile based on Price Return
for i in time_period:
    change_col = f'{i} Price Return'
    percentile_col = f'{i} Return Percentile'
    hqm_dataframe[percentile_col] = hqm_dataframe.apply(
        lambda x: score(hqm_dataframe[change_col], x[change_col]), axis=1)
```
Same method can be applied to calculate HQM Score using Pandas' `mean()` method:
```
hqm_dataframe['HQM Score'] = hqm_dataframe.apply(
    lambda x: 
    pd.Series([x[f'{time_period[0]} Return Percentile'], x[f'{time_period[1]} Return Percentile'],
               x[f'{time_period[2]} Return Percentile'], x[f'{time_period[3]} Return Percentile']
              ]).mean(), axis=1)
```

topLevelComment.author: Oleg Mazunin
topLevelComment.text:
Solved!
If you have this error:
"The frame.append method is deprecated and will be removed from pandas in a future version. Use pandas.concat instead."
There is a solution:
Instead of this: "final_dataframe = final_dataframe.append(......"
write this:

    newRow = pd.DataFrame([[
                            stock,
                            data['latestPrice'],
                            data['marketCap'],
                            'N/A'
    ]],
    columns = my_columns)
    final_dataframe = pd.concat([final_dataframe, newRow],ignore_index=True)

Incase anyone is getting the error
KeyError: 'DISCA'

I found the fix,
Basically go to the start and filter the stocks list by the below

stocks = stocks[~stocks['Ticker'].isin(['DISCA', 'HFC','VIAC','WLTW'])]

These are the stocks that have been delisted. And re run all the code and it will work after that.

What worked for me was: create .py file inside the folder called secrets. 
Inside the file you write:

import secrets

And that's it. You can call it from the Jupyter notebook. 
Also remember to activate the Sandbox Test Mode in IEX cloud.

topLevelComment.text:
Furthermore, you could try to

 1) follow the approach of Ang (2009) and exclude firms with the lowest 5% of market valuation (and not only prices <$5<$5). 

2) Exclude firms with negative book-value (common approach like e.g. in Fama/French (1992). 

3) Also, skip the most recent month for calculating momentum. This is called 2 - 12 momentum strategy.

replies.author: Will Sheehan
replies.text:
I've since figured it out 

Recommended workflow for cloning git into a virtual Python environment
1. Create an empty directory.
2. cd into it and git clone <repo> , as this will work only in empty directories.
3. create the virtual environment in a subdir in the same directory.
4. Start the VE and install requirements.

Then I did pip install Jupyter along with the other dependencies and it worked

With an editor (I used Excel), open the s&p 500 stocks csv you downloaded at the beginning (mine was named sp_500_stocks.csv).
Change: VIAC to VIAB
And Delete the following stock tickers:
HFC
WLTW
Save the csv file and rerun all your code cells and everything should work.

I'm running into an error in the momentum calculations around percentileofscore implementation, around 2h 30m mark in your video.  I am executing the following:

   for row in hqm_dataframe.index:
       for time_period in time_periods:
           change_col     = f'{time_period} Price Return'

           hqm_dataframe.loc[row, percentile_col] = score(hqm_dataframe[change_col], hqm_dataframe.loc[row, change_col])

and get the error:
   TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'NoneType' and 'float'

replies.author: Srinagesh Loke
replies.text:
I found a solution to this question in one of the comments.  Another user had the same issue and they resolved it by adding this line before the for loops I mentioned:
hqm_dataframe.dropna(inplace=True)
This drops any rows/columns that return N/A as part of f''{time_period} Price Return' column in the hqm_dataframe

topLevelComment.author: J F
topLevelComment.text:
At 2:23:39 I was dealing with the following error when trying to iterate through the percentileofscore section: TypeError: ufunc 'isnan' not supported for the input types.

If this happens to anyone else, make sure you add this above 'time_periods' to reformat the dataframe to have dtypes that are able to be handled by 'percentileof score':

hqm_dataframe = hqm_dataframe.fillna(value = np.nan)

This will replace all "None" Types with "NaN" making it possible for the 'percentileofscore' to execute as it cannot with "None." This problem may arise when dealing with sandbox data as of 09/12/21 as there are some Tickers that are no longer "in service" so to speak (e.g. CTL changed ticker symbols to LUMN but the sandbox data still has CTL as the ticker with no data associated, thus the "None" output).

topLevelComment.text: Why would you replace missing data with the average data point from the column? That's not telling you anything unique about the company you're trying to evaluate and the value of other companies in the SP500 wouldn't change the relevant metric for the given company. You should drop the stock from the dataset rather than compute an inaccurate score based on the average of the dataset. I get it as a coding exercise but there's no trading reason to do that, that I can see anyway.

topLevelComment.text:
If you guys have any issue win the Momentum strategy or the Value strategy with a:

TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'NoneType' and 'float'

this is caused by the fact that some of the P/E ratios are missing so IEX cloud simply writes 'None'

to fix this simply insert this line before your loop :

hqm_dataframe.replace([None], 0, inplace = True)

rv_dataframe.replace([None], 0, inplace = True)

you can also use the np.NaN method if you're at the value strategy

topLevelComment.author: Josh emm
topLevelComment.text: POST often ends up being used like a GET because you post a query object (which is its own data structure) and the interesting data is returned to you just like a GET would return it.  Even though this may not conform to plain logic of the design of REST it's kind of a mutation of the real world.

replies.author: Josh emm
replies.text: @No Bytes intact, is theory.  totally agree, it SHOULD be that way.  maybe they logs the GET request, then some database is changed!  maybe because POST/PUT are not cached and the query params are not shown in the URL string and cannot be bookmarked, someone decided that was a way to solve a certain problem.  I really don't know, I just know they are out there, and was pointing it out in case some API's confusing people.

replies.author: No Bytes
replies.text: @Josh emm yes mutation occurs, but not sure how that's related to a GET request. In a GET request db stays intact.

replies.author: Josh emm
replies.text: @No Bytes you are correct.  But mutation occurs in the world nonetheless.  the only rigid systems are dead systems.

replies.author: No Bytes
replies.text: Backend engineer here, this is just plain wrong. Post should only be used to send data to the server, not to be used like GET. Whoever API you're using that does this setup the endpoints wrong. There should be zero mutations  when doing GET requests.

I have a few tips for people that may be struggling with setup & other things: 
As an alternative to setting up & using a local Jupyter notebook, you can use a Google Colab Notebook (colab.research.google.com) with the following imports:

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import requests
import math
!pip install xlsxwriter

If any of you are confused about how to get secrets.py, click on the link & press 'Ctrl/Command + S' to save the file. Upload it into your Google Colab, go to the 'Runtime' menu tab, and click 'Restart & Run All'

Note that if you use Google Colabs, you may have to re-upload the stocks csv & IEX token file after you leave the browser & come back.

topLevelComment.author: Trader Joe
topLevelComment.text:
Just a hint @2:31:00 : if you are experiencing the "TypeError" issue when using the percentileofscore with the "<", use this code in the previous section first (convert_none = lambda x: 0 if x is None else x)):

hqm_columns = [
    'Ticker',
    'Price',
    'Number of Shares to buy',
    'One-Year Price Return',
    'One-Year Return Percentile',
    'Six-Month Price Return',
    'Six-Month Return Percentile',
    'Three-Month Price Return',
    'Three-Month Return Percentile',
    'One-Month Price Return',
    'One-Month Return Percentile'
]

hqm_dataframe = pd.DataFrame(columns = hqm_columns)
convert_none = lambda x : 0 if x is None else x

for symbol_string in symbol_strings: 
    batch_api_call_url = f'https://sandbox.iexapis.com/stable/stock/market/batch?symbols={symbol_string}&types=price,stats&token={IEX_CLOUD_API_TOKEN}'
    data = requests.get(batch_api_call_url).json()
    for symbol in symbol_string.split(','):
        hqm_dataframe = hqm_dataframe.append(
            pd.Series(
            [
                symbol,
                data[symbol]['price'],
                'N/A',
                convert_none(data[symbol]['stats']['year1ChangePercent']),
                'N/A',
                convert_none(data[symbol]['stats']['month6ChangePercent']),
                'N/A',
                convert_none(data[symbol]['stats']['month3ChangePercent']),
                'N/A',
                convert_none(data[symbol]['stats']['month1ChangePercent']),
                'N/A'   
            ],
            index=hqm_columns),
            ignore_index=True
        )
hqm_dataframe

I wonder if you've given thought to this strategy: often traders lose money because their stop loss gets hit and the price bounces back but the trader is no longer holding that position. What if you can write code that upon your stop loss sale, you place a limit order to buy back at the sale price? And then on the upside, you set a trailing stop loss (and if the trailing stop loss gets hit, you’d also place a limit order to rebuy the stock at the stop loss price) This strategy essentially limits your downside and lets you participate more fully on the upside, and takes the “art” out of guessing the optimal stop loss and take profit price levels. I wonder if you’ve ever considered this strategy and if you see any problems with it. Thanks in advance for your response :)

topLevelComment.author: Farzan Doroodgar
topLevelComment.text:
Not a  good video! I downvoted and therefore I am obliged to let you know of the reasons...

NOTE: I just watched the first hour of the video and fast-forwarded the next hour so I'm not sure if these complaints apply to the rest of the video as well. I skipped watching this video mainly due to the following reasons:

1) You need to work on your typing skills!! Many times when you type more than two or three words, one of them ends up misspelled and you had to go back and fix it. You may also need to do more copy/paste.
2) Your typing sound is disturbing.
3) You insist on reading much useless information that we can already read from your screen! And this takes time making your video long (e.g. Onetime you read all the columns' long-names of your data table. Dude, we can read them by ourselves)
4) You are going badly into details. Knowing how to prepare an excel file in python is totally off-topic for this specific course.
5) You must do all your thinkings and make up your mind prior to start recording. I've seen a few moments that you have been lost! For instance, you were searching for an API endpoint in the docs and you didn't even know what keyword to search for!
6) It would have been a better idea to split your video into different categories based on the course overview that you presented at the beginning of the video.
7) Sometimes your webcam's stream is covering the code cells that you are explaining and this makes it difficult to follow up.

Generally speaking, you know what to do and you are an expert at it but it's better to consider publishing shorter videos with more information rather than long videos with less information.

Good Luck

replies.author: Freddy Shimabukuro
replies.text:
Hello. 
If you're installing this on Windows 10, make sure to install the version from the python website and not from the microsoft store, since both of them install python in different locations. As for the dependencies, use the command prompt (don't use the python IDLE), and install the dependencies by typing:
pip install <dependency-name>

Replace dependency-name for the following modules:
numpy
jupyter
pandas
requests
xlsxwriter

Hope this helps you continue

topLevelComment.text:
Loving the materials!

I might add that Pandas and Numpy actually has builtin methods better suited than math and scipy libraries for some operations.

For example, numpy.floor() can be used instead of math.floor()
final_dataframe['Number of Shares to Buy'] = np.floor(position_size/final_dataframe['Price'])

or df.rank() can be used instead of scipy.stats.percentileofscore()
for time_period in time_periods:
    hqm_dataframe[f'{time_period} Return Percentile'] = hqm_dataframe[f'{time_period} Price Return'].rank(method='max', pct=True).mul(100)

topLevelComment.author: Ken Johnson
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone wondering how to clone and install the requirements (FULL SCRIPT AT BOTTOM):
1. Clone by opening a terminal in the location you want this project to go and run the command:
git clone https://github.com/nickmccullum/algorithmic-trading-python.git
2. cd into this directory you just created through the clone by running:
cd algorithmic-trading-python
3. Create a new python virtual environment by running:
python3 -m venv tutorial-env
where "tutorial-env" is the name of your virtual environment and you can name it whatever you want instead
4. Activate your virtual environment by running:
source tutorial-env/bin/activate (Linux or Mac)
tutorial-env\Scripts\activate.bat (Windows)
Look here for more info: https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/venv.html
5. Install dependencies by running:
pip3 install -r requirements.txt --use-feature=2020-resolver
6. You should be able to start working on the rest of the tutorial!
Let me know if you run into any problems, remember now every time you want to work on this program you'll have to activate your virtual environment first!
FULL SCRIPT:
git clone https://github.com/nickmccullum/algorithmic-trading-python.git
cd algorithmic-trading-python
python3 -m venv tutorial-env
source tutorial-env/bin/activate
pip3 install -r requirements.txt --use-feature=2020-resolver

replies.author: Kobe Ryan
replies.text:
The link only led me to a plain text tab. Heres a way to get around it using the command line:
1. Navigate to your project folder using the command line. Yours will be different, but mine is in Downloads so I would type: 
cd Downloads/pythonTrading 
2. Make a new file in your folder by typing: 
touch secrets.py
3. You should see the new file in the folder. Now, write the text into the file. To do this, copy the text and either paste directly in the file, or by typing: 
echo IEX_CLOUD_API_TOKEN = 'whatever the token is' >> secrets.py

replies.author: Grayson F
replies.text: @Irvin Im sure most colleges that have a business school within them will have a course or two on python or R that’s centered around finance. The course Im taking next semester is a minicourse to fill out my credit requirement so it’s probably not as in depth as youre looking for. The best place to start would probably be just googling the “python finance college course” and seeing what colleges offer that you’d be willing to pay for.
